awd_titl_txt: New methods development for structure determination of multihelical membrane proteins in their native-like lipid bilayers by solid-state NMR with applications
awd_abstract_narration:
In this Project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Alexander Nevzorov is studying membrane proteins (MPs) under their native-like conditions by solid-state Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. Membrane proteins perform a plethora of biological functions, yet the number of their solved structures remains relatively small. The solid-state NMR technique allows researchers to perform structure-function studies of MPs that are difficult or impossible to crystallize at nearly physiological conditions.  NMR spectroscopic methods developed during this research expand capabilities of this technique to multihelical MPs.

The main purpose of this project is to transform solid-state NMR of oriented membrane proteins (MPs) by developing new spectroscopic tools including methods for distance measurements and assignment of crowded spectral regions. Moreover, new membrane mimetics of flexible lipid composition based on nanopores and oriented macrodisks are being created to monitor lipid-induced conformational changes of MPs. Dynamic properties of lipid bilayers are probed including rotational diffusion of membrane-embedded proteins and the bilayer viscosity. Potential future applications include structure determination of the human Acetylcholine receptor involved in the Alzheimer's disease and other neurological disorders. As broader impacts of this project, the highly interdisciplinary nature of this research provides versatile training for the young scientists involved. As outreach activities, via mentorship of a Kenan Fellow, Dr. Nevzorov promotes the results of his research to high-school education and STEM programs.

por.por_cntn:
Membrane proteins perform a plethora of pivotal biological functions within the living cells yet the number of their three-dimensional structures remains scarce. Moreover, in most cases these structures have been obtained at cryogenic temperatures and/or low lipid-to-protein ratios. This main goal of this project is to develop a series of new experimental and computational tools for structure determination of membrane proteins by the method of solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy.  Importantly, here we emphasize sample preparation methods where membrane proteins are embedded in planar, liquid-like bilayers closely mimicking their physiological conditions, (i.e. at complete hydration and high lipid-to-protein ratios) which are macroscopically aligned relative to the main magnetic field. The tools developed over the course of this project include NMR pulse sequences and computational algorithms for structure determination of membrane proteins. As for the NMR pulse sequences, we have developed new methods for sensitivity enhancement, selective excitation, spectral editing, and measurement of the rotational diffusion coefficients by solid-state NMR. These pulse sequences allowed us to dramatically enhance the amount of structural and dynamic information obtainable from solid-state NMR spectra of aligned membrane proteins. As for computational tools, an automated method for NMR spectroscopic assignment has been developed along with a computational algorithm for structure calculations of membrane proteins from NMR data and subsequent structure validation using bioinformatics tools. These results constitute a significant progress towards de novo structure determination of membrane proteins by solid-state NMR of macroscopically aligned samples.

As for Broader and Educational Impact, the project has supported multidisciplinary research training of a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs. The student participants of this project attended conferences and workshops as part of their professional development and published their findings in peer-reviewed scientific journals. The PI's lab has hosted and sponsored a Kenan Fellow competitively selected from North Carolina high-school teachers. The Fellow was exposed to the current research developments in the PI's lab and participated in leadership courses offered by the program.   An educational module on biological membranes developed by the Fellow during the Kenan internship has been integrated into high-school Biology curricula.
